awd_titl_txt: SaTC: EDU: Collaborative: Building a Low-cost and State-of-the-art IoT Security Hands-on Laboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet of Things (IoT) interconnects everything including physical and virtual objects together through communication protocols. IoT has broad applications in digital healthcare, smart cities, transportation, agriculture, logistics and many other domains. The popularity of IoT has raised  security and privacy concerns. This project  seeks to improve IoT and privacy education through the development of laboratory module materials. This will include the development of an IoT platform with an industrial grade microcontroller (MCU) equipped with a crypto co-processor that is significantly lower-cost than existing platforms. This platform will allow for the development of a full-fledged IoT laboratory with hardware security modules at a cost that will make it affordable for students and institutions. The proposed IoT platform, teaching labs with both hardware and software, case studies and faculty development summer workshop will help improve curricula, student learning, and faculty collaboration and development at the participating institutes and partner intuitions, including Hispanic Serving Institutions and Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). 

This project is the first to use an industrial grade microcontroller and a crypto coprocessor to systematically develop teaching materials including hands-on labs and case studies on IoT security and privacy. The intellectual merit of the proposed project lies in its development of effective, engaging and novel teaching materials on IoT security. The deliverables include: a low-cost IoT development kit; the integrated development environment (IDE) to use the kit; multiple teaching labs covering the hardware security, secure key storage, secure boot, data security, network security, secure firmware upgrade and crypto co-processor; two case studies on building trustworthy air quality monitoring systems. The investigators will build awareness and competence to respond to a dynamic and rapidly developing array of cyber threats, especially those in the emerging IoT applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The popularity of Internet-of-Things (IoT) has raised grave security and privacy concerns. The research performed by the investigators of this project and related work by others have also disclosed various vulnerabilities of IoT products on market. In this project, the investigators developed a low-cost platform with an industrial grade microcontroller (MCU) ESP32 equipped with a crypto co-processor and created teaching materials including labs and case studies for IoT security education. MCUs have broad applications in IoT. Sensor nodes in various smart systems such as smart home, smart health and smart grid can use MCUs to process commands and perform automatic control. 

We have achieved the set objectives in this project. We have developed a low-cost IoT kit and Ubuntu virtual machine as the programming environment for the IoT kit for ease of adoption of the teaching materials. 

  • Ubuntu VM. It supports four programming environment. i. VS Code + PlatformIO; 2. VS Code + ESP-IDF; 3. Native ESP-IDF programming environment; 3. Arduino IDE. The first two programming environments have a GUI and are the preferred programming environments. The first three programming environments support debugging. 
  • IoT kit: 1. Breadboard version. Individual components (ESP32 development board, DHT22 temperature and humidity sensor, ATECC608 crypto co-processor, jump wires, micro-usb cable) can be purchased separately and a breadboard can be used to connect those components together. 2. PCB version. A PCB version is essentially our developed ESP32 development board and has all the components on a PCB board while an ESP32 module instead of an ESP32 development board is used on the PCB board. Here is a configuration of the latest PCB version of the IoT kit.
    • ESP32 module model
    • Temperature and humidity sensor model: AHT10
    • 0.96 inch 80*160 TFT LCD module
    • Security chip model: HSC32I1NBV60X2115, compatible with ECC608
    • 1 user LED
    • Enable and reset push-buttons
    • 1 interrupt push-button

We have finalized 16 IoT security and privacy Labs

  • Get started with ESP32 via VS Code and the ESP-IDF extension
  • Read Sensor Data and Show on Display
  • ESP32 UART and Flash Hack
  • JTAG Debugging of ESP32: PCB Version
  • JTAG Debugging of ESP32: Breadboard Version
  • Basic OTA via WiFi on ESP32
  • Secure ESP32 OTA through HTTPS
  • MITM attacks against http and https through mitmproxy
  • Network Security on ESP32 through Amazon AWS IoT: ESP-IDF original example
  • Network Security on ESP32 through Amazon AWS IoT: PlatformIO Project
  • Provisioning Crypto Coprocessor
  • ESP32 AWS IoT with Crypto Coprocessor
  • ESP32 Secure storage: Flash Encryption
  • ESP32 Secure storage: Secure Key Storage
  • ESP32 Secure Boot
  • ESP32 Software Security Demo

We have been offering the IoT security and privacy class at University of Massachusetts Lowell (UML) and University of Florida (UF) and attracted a significant number of undergraduate and graduate students. In 2023, 62 undergraduate and graduate students enrolled at UML while 71 undergraduate and graduate students from 9 different majors took part in the course at UF. 

We hosted the NSF SaTC EDU Workshop on Building a Low-cost and State-of-the-art IoT Security Hands-on Laboratory at University of Central Florida from June 29 to 30, 2023. The purpose is to disseminate the developed materials. 12 educators from US and Canada attended this two-day event. The 16 labs were introduced and attendants also had the chance of performing two hands-on labs. The travel of the participants was supported by the grant. Each participant received up to $1,000 to reimburse his or her travel expense. We mailed at least 25 IoT kits to each of the participants.

Our evaluator has performed evaluations on all the developed labs and workshop. The evaluation results demonstrated the success of the developed labs. Students and workshop participants like the IoT kit and developed labs, which cover hardware security, system/firmware/software security, network security and data security.
